one thing (and they might have already started doing this) that would make these sights much more relevant is if they offered purity testing. so you pour out a couple grains of your stash and they test it for cuts like fentanyl. that would be a great implementation if feasible.

i probably saw the same one. i certainly don't think homeless opiate addicts aren't a problem worth addressing. but we should be careful not frame the opiate epidemic at large as limited to this particular set of parameters.

there's such a range. alot of ppl who experienced intense trauma are really effed up and are allured into an opiate addiction. but they wld be effed up without access to opiates too. these sites wld offer nothing to the majority of addicts. they're for homeless addicts.

yes...and i think, depending on the size of the city and opiate problem inherent....publically funded vans that drive around on a daily schedule (that addicts become accustomed too) is probably more effective. most addicts don't actually go to the trouble of using the sites.

it's just a clean environment an addict can go to where they can get fresh needles to use whatever they have been able to cop during the day. it's thought that by getting them to go there....they can be checked up on...make relationships with staff....get access to services.
no. the addicts bring their own drugs to the site. all that is offered is a clean environment and clean needles. and access to counselling/related-services.

but the sites do become places where alot of ppl hang around outside and around it becomes a general meeting place for ppl who sell/use.
very few addicts actually 'use' the site because there's not much to offer to someone who just wants to get high.

the safe injection sites in canada do not provide any dose. those drugs are still illegal. they only offer a clean environment and clean works to do whatever an addict has attained off the street. you get your stuff. you go to the site. they give you needles. that's it.

i think we also tend to have much longer periods of use/dependence bc there's less motivation, or ultimatums given by our peers. when there's less life consequences to the usage....it tends to go on much longer creating a much stronger physical dependence.

it's almost a curse in a way. we end up doing drugs much more regularly which results in much stronger physical addictions. irrational users go thru regular dry spells. rational ones maintain much steadier habits.

i could be totally wrong...but i think of functioning addicts, like myself, simply as highly rational ppl who love drugs. that's all it is. i would make rational choices. ie "can't do it all tonight bc then i won't have any tomorrow".
i'll tentatively say substance dependence but i'd have to become more familiar with the differences to commit. i think even functioning addicts have alot to gain in getting sober.

i'd have a sensitivity re-awakening. music felt better. sentimental stories hit home harder. love was more intense. sad things sadder. happy things happier. so even those who don't satisfy the pragmatic def of addiction, i think sobriety is still something work seeking imo.

i love capitalism. but i also don't think it's the end of history. new circumstances arise (are arising). there's no reason to think that the same solutions that worked in the past necessarily work in the future.

right. we don't deconstruct the term 'work' to negate it's use. we deconstruct the term 'works' to realize that when we do use it...we are doing so pragmatically (sort of speak). your resistors are using some form of invalid deconstructionism that is transparently inconsistent
it's an irony becuase you are the one deconstucting language by employing the pragmatic def and they are the ones employing the correspondance def. i don't think they are aware of this irony.

paraprasing: "one can't simply say a car doesn't work....there must be an identifiable state of some element of the car that justifies whether or not we classify it as working or not working'. that was their counter-argument to you.
they went on about carborators and transmissions and stuff.
yes i know that. my point is that the resistance to your use of pragmatic definition was, by the people who posed the resistance....an 'unknowing return to correspondance theory of truth'.
thus the term 'pragmatic definition' which is disinct from 'correspondance definition'.
yes but it was asked of you to define what 'works' means. and the implication was....if a universal definition of 'works' could not be provided.....then the assertion was nonsensical.

within these debates i've seen  say: 'for all intents and purposes...when i say my car doesn't work...99% of ppl nod their head in understanding' it's insisted there must be an identifiable def. of 'works' if understanding is to exist which is correspondance theory

this has been clear in the discussions of the meaning of 'work' in regard to dawkin's recent post about eugenics. since we can't define what 'works' means....the whole argument is thrown up in the air as nonsense. but this is the correspondance approach to language and truth.

the irony....is that by claiming because a chair cannot be defined....that's it's use in language is somehow no longer legitimate.....is itself an implicit turn back into the correspondance theory of truth without knowing one is making the return.

the whole 'what is a chair' question was meant to break down previous assumptions. if you sit on a foot-stool it's effectively a 'chair' sure. but the intention was never to claim that 'there are no such things as chairs'.

even the acknowledgement of 'pragmatic classification' is a step away from correspondence truth. i spent alotta time thinking about wittgenstein's philosophical investigations. the language deconstructionists have taken half of it and waged a war that he never intended.

this is why the drug is so often referred to as seductive. it's not like booze or psychedelics or the sudden rush of a stimulant. it's a very hard to grasp sense of well-being that seems extremely innocent. until it doesn't.

but that's the nature of opiates in the first place. i'm sure if you took 20 mgs of oxy you would say 'this doesn't have a big effect on me'. everyone does. because opiates are much more subtle than other drugs like coke, herb, x....all which have a much more obvious impact....
in my opinion...this substance is more undcomfortable to stop taking than crack. seriously. at least have a poke through these threads and testimonies:
tbh....i would suggest never taking it more than one day at a time. never two days in a row.

yah. what i've heard is that red and green are the the two polar opposites. everything else is on some scale in between. because i take it primarily for opiate addiction treatment....i only order red. i've tried green though and it definitely felt like speed.
green leaf has probably been linked to weight loss because of it's similarity of effect as amphetamines.

making things even more confusing....opiates themselves are stimulating in small doses. so even red-leaf kratom is stimulating even if sedating in large doses. but i generally concur that green leaf is similar to adderall/dexedrine/speed and red leaf similar to dope.

there's mixed opinions about this. but there's several different types of kratom leaves which mostly depend on when and where they are harvested. generally speaking....'green leaf' is thought to be simulating. 'red leaf' thought to be sedating and pain-killing (opiate-like).
experienced synthetic opiate withdrawal. not a picnic for anyone who hasn't. and it comes on faster than other drugs. it really shouldn't be played with imo.

i'll say this again....for anyone unfamiliar with opiate withdrawal....i think they would be shocked by the severity of discomfort kratom wd is. there's tons of anecdotal evidence on bluelight forum. thousands of ppl sharing kratom wd stories. relatively easy for those who've...

if used 3 times a day for more than 2 or 3 months....one would typically go through an approx 5 to 7 day withdrawal. and like opiates...you can't drink yourself out of it (like you can crack/cocaine). alcohol makes the wd symptoms worse. but again...it's a matter of degree.
my hope for kratom is not that everyone use it recreationally. my hope is that it is used in place of opiates for some short term pain management and most importantly, for addiction treatment.

scenario 1: tie game, attempt a 20 yard field goal on last play of game scenario 2: new england down by 7 gets possession at their own 20 with 60 seconds left. they opted for 2.

hmmm...not sure. one of the most inventive coaching decisions i remember is when brady allowed a team to score a touchdown (the defensive players just stopped playing) because the time left on the clock was more valuable than the 7 points they gave up. hadn't seen that before.
in moneyball it was referred to with bunting. managers will opt to bunt (the conventional decision) even when it's not the sound decision to avoid the wrath of the press after the game.

moneyball touches on why nfl coaches still refuse to go for 4th down conversions. even when the odds suggest they should....managers are worried about the perception of the decision if it fails. they'd prefer to take the less controversial option than the mathematically sound one
yep. 10 years ago...it was a common decision to go for 2 in such a situation. it only happens now when the coach vetoes his sabermetric analyst.

one of my fave aspects of moneyball was research into why conventional statistics have been misleading. for ex, walks were under-estimated in baseball (via batting avg) bc the guy who invented the metric was a cricket expert (there's no equivalent of a walk in cricket)
the psychological difference in margins that aren't divisible by 7 and 3 are very misleading.
in anycase...this has been studied. 2 point conversion attempts before the 4th quarter are down something like 96% the past 10 years.

i'm assuming every team has the mean conversion rate. any difference would be irrelevant because they're extremely small sample sizes. the coach should decide based on the league average. the difference between score diffs that aren't divisible by 7 or 3 are underestimated.
it's only in the final minutes...when potential subsequent scoring sequences become less and less likely that a 2 point conversion should ever be attempted.

i was referring to: 2nd quarter. just scored a touchdown. down by 16. might as well go for 2 right? because there's no difference in being down by 15 or 16? wrong. because it doesn't account for subsequent scoring plays. it was a common error. it's rare now but still happens.
2 point conversions are only useful in the final minutes wherein subsequent scoring scenarios are less likely.

in basketball....the frequency of three point shots was a huge sabermetric advancement: https://www.teamrankings.com/nba/stat/three-pointers-attempted-per-game?date=2006-06-21 compared to: https://www.teamrankings.com/nba/stat/three-pointers-attempted-per-game?date=2019-06-14 a huge game-changer
in football...i highly suspect that sabermetric analysis would show that more teams should go for '4th and short' scenarios. also...going for 2 points should never happen til the final minutes.
baseball is the most interesting sport to analyze. everything is quantifiable and there are so many potential metrics.

right. this has been a fruitful thread. i think the nuances in diagnosing what is happening are crucial. as shorthand...i generally use "woke culture' or 'grievance studies' for what i perceive to be a hybrid of ct and pomo. i know that pluckrose et al disagree with this tho.
we should note that in regards to the meaning of words....authority via consensus is distinct from authority based on representational theories of truth.

yes because any notion of consensus betrays the underlying assumption of social conflict theory. that all interactions are a function of conflict between groups. so any analysis based on consensus to analyze human interaction serves only to re-enforce existing power hierarchies.

the critical theorists that mentored me used the film 'rashomon' to articulate their critique of pomo. particularly the final scene where the truth relativist abandons the baby in the rain and the protagonist saves it. truth is only relative if we don't care about it.

also that the very notion of suffering depends on a definition that itself can be deconstructed to render it meaningless just like everything else. so yes...this process of deconstruction only advocates for anything if it is selectively applied.

i find it somewhat ironic that some of the best critiques of postmodernism came from critical theorists. although i'm skeptical about both ideologies....i think we will all benefit when the distinction between the two becomes clearer such as it was before 2010ish.

i can only offer my perception. i'm relatively familiar with ct bc i studied it in the 90s. my perception is that it has permeated every facet of modern social life.....including media, news, television, films, music, popular discourse, social media platforms, etc.

i certainly can't quantify/prove it. but a typical 8 hour shift of mixing the audio on the canadian cnn....my estimate is around 70% of the social scientists we skype with on-air are ct proponents to some degree (often just judging by the terms they use).

i'm not an academic but when something goes down politically we'll have all sorts of academic pundits on skype commenting with expertise. grads, phds, profs, etc. there's a huge generational gap to which critical theory is present in their rhetoric and views.

i work for a 24 hour national newschannel (the canadian cnn). every pundit we have on the show that is under the age of 30 is absolutely knee-deep in critical theory. everything from entertainment media to poli-sci grads. my station is traditionally right of center (right of cbc)
